title: fix: add `allowed_for_roles` to manage `RemoteFeedbackDataset` permissions
body:
# Description

This PR adds `allowed_for_roles` for `RemoteFeedbackDataset`, `RemoteFeedbackRecords`, and `RemoteFeedbackRecord` when needed, as the `annotator` cannot do most of the operations.

Since the `RemoteFeedbackDataset`, `RemoteFeedbackRecords`, and `RemoteFeedbackRecord` are just intended to be used from either an `owner` or an `admin`, we should probably restrict everything to those roles only.

Closes #3545

title: [BUG] Workspace filtering doesn't work as intended

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

body: **Describe the bug** When having more than one workspace starting with the same string e.g. `argilla`, the workspace filtering is not working as intended, since assuming we have the workspaces `argilla`, `argillaworkspace`, `argilla-workspace`, and `argilla_workspace`, the only filter that works as intended is the `argilla` one, while the rest of them will include `argilla` as part of the workspaces being filtered. This means that the filtering is not looking for exact matches between the string to use as a filter and the workspace names, since when filtering by `argilla-workspace` only the datasets assigned to `argilla-workspace` should be shown, not also the ones in `argilla`. Note that `argilla` is the one used for showcasing purposes, but it also happens with any workspace naming sharing the same starting string plus something else, which can either be another string, an allowed special symbol plus another string, etc. Also note that the URL looks fine and the workspace filter is properly included e.g. `https:///datasets?workspaces=argilla-workspace` **To Reproduce** Steps to reproduce the behaviour: 1. Create N workspaces and M datasets assigned to those workspaces 2. Go to Argilla UI where you created those workspaces and datasets 3. Click on the `Workspace` filter, and select the checkboxes individually to see that the results always include `argilla`, and not just the filtered one **Expected behaviour** The filter to work with an exact match to avoid including workspaces that are not selected. **Screenshots** **Video** https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/36760800/7a440154-6f98-45e3-8fb7-4a211c679449 **Environment (please complete the following information):** - OS [e.g. iOS]: macOS - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Arc (based on Chromium) - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.14.1 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: N/A - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: argilla:v1.14.1

title: fix: change drop_duplicates to work on columns contaning lists

title: [FEATURE] Add an `ArgillaTrainer.load` method to load the data generated by `ArgillaTrainer.train(output_dir=...)`
body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls If you'd like to discuss your feature request or specific needs with our product team, contact Natalia Elvira in our slack community or book a slot with her: https://calendly.com/natalia-elvira/30min -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently the `ArgillaTrainer` has a method to `save` the trained models, but there is no one to load them back.

```python
trainer = ArgillaTrainer(...)
trainer.train(output_dir="output_dir")
...
trainer = ArgillaTrainer.load("output_dir")
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
An `ArgillaTrainer.load` method to load from the directory created when `ArgillaTrainer.save` is called.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
None

**Additional context**
Transformers models have a `.from_pretrained` method to load a model from a local directory, and spacy has `spacy.load`, it would simplify loading a model after fine-tuning as such.
If you think the request makes sense, I'll be glad to take it.

```shell
python -m argilla users create --username gabrielmbmb --password user_password --first-name Gabriel --last-name Martin --role owner --workspace workspace1 --workspace workspace2
```

body:
Add a new command that will list the workspaces to which the logged in belongs. The command will make use of `argilla.client.workspace.Workspace` class and its method `list` to get the workspaces to which the user belongs. As `rich` is a dependency of Argilla, use [`rich.table.Table`](https://rich.readthedocs.io/en/stable/tables.html) to display the workspaces.

The table will contain the following columns: `ID`, `Name`, `Creation Date` and `Update Date`.

```shell
python -m argilla workspaces list
```

title: Move users current `users` CLI app under `database` CLI app

labels.name: good first issue
labels.description: Indicates a good issue for first-time contributors

body:
Currently, Argilla CLI app has a group of commands [`python -m argilla users`](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/tree/develop/src/argilla/tasks/users) that allows to manage users connecting directly to the database.

In #3579, we are planning to add a new group of commands that will allow to manage users connecting to the API instead of directly connecting to the database, therefore, we need to move the current `users` group of commands under [`python -m argilla database`](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/tree/develop/src/argilla/tasks/database) so these commands can get executed using `python -m argilla database users`.

This would imply moving `argilla.tasks.users` subpackage to `argilla.tasks.database.users` subpackage and then adding the `users` Typer app as a subapplication of `database` Typer app using [Add Typer](https://typer.tiangolo.com/tutorial/subcommands/add-typer/)

```python
import argilla as rg
```

title: [FEATURE] Improve CLI to include basic operations

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Right now the CLI of Argilla mainly supports management operations for the server like migrating the database or creating users directly connecting to the database.

It would be good to be able to login in an Argilla server from the CLI and later be able to perform some operations like creating users or workspaces.
```
$ argilla login https://dev.argilla.io/ --username gabrielmbmb
Password:
Logged in https://dev.argilla.io/
$ argilla workspaces create my_project
Created `my_project` workspace in https://dev.argilla.io/
$ argilla users create --username gabrielmbmb --workspace my_project
User `gabrielmbmb` created!
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Update the CLI interface to add a login command that will store the credentials locally in order to be able to call later other commands for creating workspaces, users, etc. In addition, these locally store credentials could be used as a fallback if `rg.init` is not called.

The current command for creating users directly connecting to the database should be moved under `argilla database users` or similar.

**Additional context**
Right now, you need to create a python script to create users and workspaces, which is mostly fine, but in some cases it can be a bit cumbersome.



title: [BUG] Clicking the workspace doesn't always filter correctly

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: ui
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the User Interface (UI)

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

**Describe the bug**
Clicking on the workspace in the top bar of an Argilla dataset redirects to `workspace=...` instead of `workspaces=...`. The former doesn't work anymore.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. browse to a Dataset, e.g.: https://dev.argilla.io/dataset/38c2461d-4c23-4972-bb38-9a87125d0ac1
2. Click on the workspace in the top bar:
![image](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/37621491/e310482c-92ba-46df-90e2-942bef243822)
3. Observe that it redirects to `workspace=workspace-0` instead of `workspaces=workspace-0`:
![image](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/assets/37621491/7083bcc4-4258-4dda-b097-8c8fc48cf03f)


**Expected behavior**
I expect it to open `workspaces=workspace-0`, as only that one works with filtering.

**Screenshots**
See above.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]: Windows
 - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Firefox
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.14.0-dev
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: Unsure, whatever dev's on
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]:

**Additional context**
NOTE: This is only for FeedbackDataset it seems! On e.g. https://dev.argilla.io/datasets/recognai/issue_2353_emoji (a TokenClassification dataset) it works fine.

- Tom Aarsen

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
In order to delete a record from a `FeedbackDataset`, one request has to be made to the server. This mades `FeedbackDataset.delete_records` method extremely slow if many records have to be deleted as one request per record to be removed will be sent to the server.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Add an endpoint in the server that allows to remove multiple records. Update the Python client to use this new endpoint when more than one record has to be removed.

```[tasklist]
### Tasks
- [x] Add delete records endpoint
- [x] Update `RemoteFeedbackDataset.delete_records` method to use the new endpoint
```

title: fix: cannot update ranking & rating question with `settings`
body:
# Description

The input payload for updating a question was not consistent across the different types of questions. For the `text`, `label_selection` and `multi_label_selection`, it is necessary to provide the kind of question to be updated including `{"settings": {"type": "question_type"}` in the input payload, while for the `rating` and `ranking` question it was not needed to provide the `settings` and when provided it caused a validation error. This was because this last two questions types didn't have a `pydantic.BaseModel` included in the `QuestionUpdateSettings` discriminator causing the following payloads to not be valid when updating them:

```json
{
   "name": "New Name",
    "settings": {
        "type": "ranking"
    }
}
```

and the only valid payload was:

```json
{
   "name": "New Name"
}
```

To keep the consistency in the input payload for updating a question, this PR include two new `pydantic.BaseModel`, one for rating and one for ranking question, that are included in the `QuestionUpdateSettings` discriminator so the payload mentioned above is valid when updating a `ranking` or `rating` question.

**Type of change**

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

**How Has This Been Tested**

Unit tests has been updated and manual tests on local environment.

body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

I added support for the PPOTrainer.

```python
from transformers import pipeline
from trl import PPOConfig

task_mapping = TrainingTask.for_proximal_policy_optimization(text=dataset.field_by_name("text"))
trainer = ArgillaTrainer(
    dataset=dataset,
    task=task_mapping,
    framework="trl",
    fetch_records=False
)
# assuming we have an arbitrarily trained textcat model
reward_model = pipeline("sentiment-analysis", model="lvwerra/distilbert-imdb")
trainer.update_config(reward_model=sentiment_pipe) # this is always required but if not done it provides a warning
trainer.train(output_dir="my_awesone_model")
```

Closes #3522

title: [BUG] Argilla server returns `422` if field name contains uppercase letter

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
**Describe the bug**
The server returns a `422` when trying to create a field whose name contains uppercase letters.

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**
```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(api_url="http://localhost:6900", api_key="owner.apikey")

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    guidelines="test",
    fields=[
        rg.TextField(name="question"),
        rg.TextField(name="completion-A"),
        rg.TextField(name="completion-B"),
    ],
    questions=[
        rg.RankingQuestion(
            name="completion-ranking",
            description="Rank the completions.",
            values=["top-1", "top-2"],
            required=True
        ),
    ]
)


dataset.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="gabrielmbmb")
```
**Expected behavior**
`TextField` (`FieldSchema`) raise a `ValidationError` before calling the server if the `name` contains an uppercase letter. Ideally, the `FieldSchema.name` attribute should have the same validations as in the server.

**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.13.3
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]:
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]:

**Additional context**
This issue was originally reported by @acjones27 in the Slack community channel.

title: fix: Argilla not working behind proxy
body:
# Description

This PR updates the URL in which the Argilla App is mounted to be `"/"`, as it's not required to change the URL of the server because the proxy will know what rewrite has to be done.

In addition, the entrypoint scripts of both images have been updated to add the `--root-path $ARGILLA_BASE_URL` option to the `uvicorn` command if `ARGILLA_BASE_URL` env variable has been set. title: [BUG] Argilla not working behind proxy

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
**Describe the bug**
Argilla is not working properly when working behind a proxy. Given the following `docker-compose.yaml`:

```yaml
version: '3.8'

services:
  argilla:
    image: argilla/argilla-quickstart:v1.13.3
    environment:
      ARGILLA_BASE_URL: /argilla
      LOAD_DATASETS: none
    ports:
      - 6900:6900

  nginx:
    image: nginx:latest
    ports:
      - 80:80
    volumes:
      - ./nginx.conf:/etc/nginx/nginx.conf
 ```

and the following `nginx.conf`:

```
http {
  server {
      listen 80;

      server_name your_server_name_or_ip;

      location /argilla/ {
          proxy_pass http://argilla:6900/;
          proxy_set_header Host $host;
          proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
          proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
          proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
      }
  }
}
```

The Argilla server is returning `{"detail":"Not Found"}` when accessing `localhost/argilla` from a web browser and to connect using the Python client the following code is required:

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(api_url="http://localhost/argilla/argilla", api_key="owner.apikey")
```
Adding the extra `/argilla` shouldn't be required.

**Expected behavior**

Argilla UI loads when configured behind a proxy and to connect to the server from the Python client it's not required adding extra URL paths.

**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.13.3
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]:
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: argilla/argilla-quickstart:v1.13.3

**Additional context**
This issue was originally reported by Chris Ballard in the [Slack community channel](https://rubrixworkspace.slack.com/archives/C02G2TZFG3V/p1691407463360219).

title: [FEATURE] allow for both `formatting_func` and in `ArgillaTrainer` tasks

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: area: trainer
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Argilla Trainer

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls If you'd like to discuss your feature request or specific needs with our product team, contact Natalia Elvira in our slack community or book a slot with her: https://calendar.app.google/FMCLVV7PfDJ3A4Hp7 -->

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Now there is a slight fragmentation in the customizability vs. out-of-the-box functionality of the `ArgillaTrainer`, where some tasks are initialized with a `formatting_func` (PPO, DPO, SFT, RM) for preparing data and others with fixed `texts` and `fields`. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Ideally, we would like to have some out-of-the-box defaults and unification measures but also ofter the option to have a custom `formatting_func` for each individual task. Or, at least 

- `TrainingTaskForSFT` can have a default `TextField`-`TextQuestion` format.
- `TrainingTaskForRM` can have a default `TextQuestion`+unification format.
  - unifying per rank difference. 
  - unifying only the best vs worse ranked example
  - open to suggestions
- `TrainingTaskForPPO` by default we could just use an arbitrary `TextField` as input, which is good enough as a default, but if you happen to have prompt and context in multiple `TextField`s, we might want to use a custom function.
- `TrainingTaskForDPO` can combine both of the above
- `TrainingTaskForTextClassification` could use a `formatting_func` to allow for more flexibility in textfield creation, combining multiple fields for example.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N.A.

**Additional context**
As briefly discussed with @tomaarsen

title: fix: restore `suggestions` and `responses` as rows in `HuggingFaceDatasetMixin`
body:
# Description

This PR addresses the feature mentioned by @tomaarsen at https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/3467, to basically export the `responses` for the existing questions in the `FeedbackDataset` when calling `push_to_huggingface` in a row-based format instead of using the `Sequence` from 🤗`datasets`. This makes the dataset from the HuggingFace Hub more readable, and also easier to use with other frameworks and/or libraries.

```diff
- {"user_id": ["A", "B"], "value": [1, 2], "status": ["C", "D"]}
+ [{"user_id": "A", "value": 1, "status": "C"}, {"user_id": "B", "value": 2, "status": "D"}]
```

Additionally, this PR also ensure that the backwards compatibility is preserved with the previous versions, and assumes the new format as the default one when calling `format_as("datasets")`.

Finally, this PR also solves an issue reported by @nataliaelv recently that was affecting the `suggestions` when calling `FeedbackDataset.from_argilla`, as those were just kept when there were `responses`, otherwise, a `continue` statement was being called so the `suggestions` were completely ignored.

**Type of change**

- [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)
- [X] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

(Please describe the tests that you ran to verify your changes. And ideally, reference `tests`)

- [X] Ran the following script and tested different combinations as the connection to HuggingFace is mocked, but we should create a fake/testing user at some point to avoid overloading `argilla-io`

```python
import argilla as rg

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(
    fields=[
        rg.TextField(
            name="prompt",
            required=True,
        ),
    ],
    questions=[
        rg.TextQuestion(
            name="response-edit",
            title="Add or edit the response if necessary",
            required=True,
        ),
    ],
)
dataset.add_records(
    rg.FeedbackRecord(
        fields={
            "prompt": "This is the prompt!",
        },
        suggestions=[
            {
                "question_name": "response-edit",
                "value": "This is the suggestion!"
            }
        ],
    )
)
dataset.push_to_huggingface("<REPO_ID>")
dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset.from_huggingface("<REPO_ID>")
assert dataset.records[0].suggestions is not None
```

title: feat: delete existing records from a `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla
body:
# Description

This PR adds `delete_record` function in the SDK covering `DELETE /api/v1/records/{record_id}` to also include: a `delete` method for `RemoteFeedbackRecord` to delete records from Argilla, a `delete` method for `RemoteFeedbackRecords`, a `delete_records` method in `RemoteFeedbackDataset` as a shortcut for the previous one.

So on, this implies that now we can either do in place deletions as:

```python
import argilla as rg

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset.from_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")
dataset.records[0].delete()
```

Or also deleting a list of records via `delete_records` as:

```python
import argilla as rg

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset.from_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")

dataset.delete_records([record for record in dataset.records])
```

Additionally, note that when calling `.delete()` over a `RemoteFeedbackRecord`, it will return the record instance as a `FeedbackRecord` so that it can be used locally and pushed again, if applicable.

```python
deleted_record = dataset.records[0].delete()
```

body:
Updates the requirements on [wrapt](https://github.com/GrahamDumpleton/wrapt) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from wrapt's changelog.

Version 1.15.0

Bugs Fixed

  • When the C extension for wrapt was being used, and a property was used on an object proxy wrapping another object to intercept access to an attribute of the same name on the wrapped object, if the function implementing the property raised an exception, then the exception was ignored and not propagated back to the caller. What happened instead was that the original value of the attribute from the wrapped object was returned, thus silently suppressing that an exception had occurred in the wrapper. This behaviour was not happening when the pure Python version of wrapt was being used, with it raising the exception. The pure Python and C extension implementations thus did not behave the same.

    Note that in the specific case that the exception raised is AttributeError it still wouldn't be raised. This is the case for both Python and C extension implementations. If a wrapper for an attribute internally raises an AttributeError for some reason, the wrapper should if necessary catch the exception and deal with it, or propagate it as a different exception type if it is important that an exception still be passed back.

  • Address issue where the post import hook mechanism of wrapt wasn't transparent and left the __loader__ and __spec__.loader attributes of a module as the wrapt import hook loader and not the original loader. That the original loader wasn't preserved could interfere with code which needed access to the original loader.

  • Address issues where a thread deadlock could occur within the wrapt module import handler, when code executed from a post import hook created a new thread and code executed in the context of the new thread itself tried to register a post import hook, or imported a new module.

  • When using CallableObjectProxy as a wrapper for a type or function and calling the wrapped object, it was not possible to pass a keyword argument named self. This only occurred when using the pure Python version of wrapt and did not occur when using the C extension based implementation.

  • When using PartialCallableObjectProxy as a wrapper for a type or function, when constructing the partial object and when calling the partial object, it was not possible to pass a keyword argument named self. This only occurred when using the pure Python version of wrapt and did not occur when using the C extension based implementation.

  • When using FunctionWrapper as a wrapper for a type or function and calling the wrapped object, it was not possible to pass a keyword argument named self. Because FunctionWrapper is also used by decorators, this also affected decorators on functions and class types. A similar issue also arose when these were applied to class and instance methods where binding occurred

title: feat: add `delete` method to `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
# Description

This PR adds a `delete` method for `RemoteFeedbackDataset` which is a `FeedbackDataset` that has been pushed to Argilla. So on, the `delete` method deletes a dataset in Argilla, but it's just available for `owner` users and for `admin` users with that dataset within their workspace, otherwise the method won't work and will raise a `PermissionError`.

So on, now both `owner` and `admin` users can delete a `FeedbackDataset` from Argilla as:

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(...)

dataset = FeedbackDataset.from_argilla(...)
dataset.delete()
```

Or alternatively

```python
import argilla as rg

rg.init(...)

dataset = FeedbackDataset(...)
remote_dataset = dataset.push_to_argilla(...)
remote_dataset.delete()
```

Closes #3413

fix: `push_to_argilla` to return `RemoteFeedbackDataset` without re-assigning class

labels.name: type: breaking changes
labels.description: This issue or PR may include breaking changes in the code

body:
# Description

This PR adds a `warnings.warn` message to let the users know that the returned object from `FeedbackDataset.push_to_argilla` needs to be handled, otherwise the dataset instance will remain local, as `push_to_argilla` with no arguments won't do anything.

So on, before we had to `push_to_argilla` a new `FeedbackDataset` with name and/or workspaces, and then we could `push_to_argilla` with no arguments to push the updates, but we no longer need to do that, as now we can re-use the returned `FeedbackDataset` from `push_to_argilla` to have a `FeedbackDataset` fully integrated with Argilla.

```diff
import argilla as rg

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(...)
- dataset.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")
+ remote_dataset = dataset.push_to_argilla(name="my-dataset", workspace="my-workspace")

dataset.add_records(...)
- dataset.push_to_argilla()
```

body:
# Description

This PR updates the current CI workflow to add an extra job that will automatically deploy the built quickstart image to Google Cloud Run so the changes made can be tested in an isolated environment.

When the PR is closed or merged, the deployment in Google Cloud Run will be automatically removed.

**Type of change**

- [x] New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

I've opened #3513 PR to test the deploy and teardown workflows:

- Build package workflow: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/actions/runs/5776403769
  - [x] Branch deployed to Cloud Run
- Close PR workflow: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/actions/runs/5776562105
  - [x] Environment for the PR was removed

**Checklist**

- [ ] I added relevant documentation
- [x] follows the style guidelines of this project
- [x] I did a self-review of my code
- [ ] I made corresponding changes to the documentation
- [x] My changes generate no new warnings
- [ ] I have added tests that prove my fix is effective or that my feature works
- [ ] I filled out [the contributor form](https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK) (see text above)
- [ ] I have added relevant notes to the CHANGELOG.md file (See https://keepachangelog.com/)

title: [BUG] Workspace not found in `rg.configure_dataset`

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/alvarobartt-argilla or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

**Describe the bug**
When using the method `rg.configure_dataset(name="my_dataset", workspace="my_workspace", settings=settings)` the following error occurs:

```
BadRequestApiError: Argilla server returned an error with http status: 400
Error details: [{'code': 'argilla.api.errors::MissingInputParamError', 'params': {'message': 'A workspace must be 
provided'}}] 
````

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**
```python
rg.init(
    api_url="API_URL",
    api_key="API_KEY"
)
settings = rg.TextClassificationSettings(label_schema = ["a", "b", "c"])
rg.configure_dataset(name="my_dataset", workspace="my_workspace", settings= settings)
```

**Expected behavior**
The dataset is found correctly and the new configuration is pushed.

This can be solved by setting a workspace beforehand using `rg.set_workspace("my_workspace")`, but it would be good to be able to skip that step and set the workspace as an attribute of `configure_dataset` directly.

**Environment:**
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.13.3
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]:
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]:

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

title: fix: `DatasetConfig.to_yaml` and `DatasetConfig.from_yaml` to ignore `UUID`
body:
# Description

As recently reported by @nataliaElv we had some issues while calling `FeedbackDataset.from_huggingface` as the `argilla.yaml` file couldn't be read properly. This was due to an incompatibility between the UUIDs and PyYAML, which is now patched.

We will no longer be dumping the `id` fields for both `fields` and `questions` since those are useless outside Argilla and we cannot use those to recreate a `FeedbackDataset` in Argilla, and when loading those back from HuggingFace we'll remove the `id` first with a regex to avoid loading issues.

**Type of change**

- [X] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [X] Move `test_config.py` to unit tests as it's not calling the API
- [X] Add some assertions in `test_config.py` to ensure that the `id`s are neither dumped nor loaded from `argilla.yaml`

**Checklist**
